required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Trial to Investigate Safety and Efficacy of Edoxaban in Patients With CTEPH (KABUKI)
clinical_study.official_title: An Investigator-initiated, Multicenter, Phase 3, Randomized, Single-blind, Double-dummy, Parallel-group Study of Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Edoxaban Versus Warfarin (Vitamin K Antagonist) in Subjects With Chronic Thromboembolic Pulmonary Hypertension Taking Warfarin (Vitamin K Antagonist) at Baseline: KABUKI

brief_summary.textblock: This is phase III trial to evaluate whether edoxaban, a direct factor Xa inhibitor, is noninferior to warfarin in preventing worsening of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH).

primary_outcome.measure: Ratio of 1-year resting PVR to baseline resting PVR

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of cases with CTEPH exacerbation events
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout the study duration(up to week48)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in distance of 6-minute walking test
Change from baseline in WHO functional classification class
Change from baseline in NT-proBNP concentration
Percentage of cases with clinically significant bleeding
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Throughout the study duration(up to week48)

intervention.description: - Edoxaban 30 mg/60 mg tablet according to body weight. 60 kg or less: 30 mg once daily, over 60 kg: 60 mg once daily, reduced to 30 mg once daily depending on renal function and concomitant medications
- Warfarin K 1 mg tablets once daily (Dose adjusted with target PT-INR of 1.5-2.5)
- Warfarin K 1 mg placebo tablets once daily

- Edoxaban 30 mg/60 mg placebo tablet according to body weight. 60 kg or less: 30 mg once daily, over 60 kg: 60 mg once daily, reduced to 30 mg once daily depending on renal function and concomitant medications

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Patient who once* diagnosed with CTEPH based on imaging study (VQ scan, CT pulmonary angiogram) and hemodynamic criteria (MPAP >=25 mmHg and PAWP =< 15 mmHg). *Patients treated with PEA, BPA, or vasodilators, who do not meet hemodynamic criteria at the registration, are eligible.
2. Patients who are not planned to require increased / changed / discontinuation of PEA, BPA, or pulmonary vasodilators within 12months
3. Stable administration of vitamin K antagonists
4. WHO functional class I-III
5. Patients who meet A) B)and C) by 90 days prior to baseline. A)No addition, reduction, or change of endothelin antagonists, soluble guanylate cyclase stimulants, phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors, prostacyclin, and its derivatives, or calcium antagonists. B)Appropriate anticoagulants have been continued. C)No BPA has been done.
6. Patients who have not undergone PEA from 180 days prior to baseline right heart catheterization to the start date of study drug administration
7. Patients with a 6-minute walking distance >=150m
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Patients with severe lung disease (FEV1.0/FVC < 60% or %TLC < 60%)
2. Patients with acute or chronic disabilities that interfere with clinical trial requirements
3. Patients with acute symptomatic PE within 180 days prior to the start of study drug administration
4. Patients with congenital heart disease who have not undergone radical surgery
5. Patients who cannot provide informed consent due to mental disorders, dementia, or other illnesses
6. Patients with advanced cancer
7. Patients with a life expectancy of less than 1 year
8. Patients with active hemorrhagic lesions
9. Patients with comorbidities requiring vitamin K antagonist
10. Patients receiving other study drug within 30 days prior to randomization
11. Patients with renal dysfunction (Ccr 15 mL/min)
12. Patients with liver dysfunction (Child-Pugh B or C)
13. Females of reproductive age not using an acceptable form of contraception/Pregnant/Breastfeeding
14. Patients contraindicated for edoxaban or warfarin
15. Patients with hypersensitivity to any of the drug

reference.citation: Hosokawa K, Abe K, Tsutsui H. Use of direct oral anticoagulants prevents increase in pulmonary vascular resistance and incidence of clinical worsening in patients with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension. Thromb Res. 2019 Aug;180:43-46. doi: 10.1016/j.thromres.2019.05.018. Epub 2019 May 31.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Department of Cardiovascular Medicine, Faculty of Medical Sciences
